content.webTitle: Dutch experiences provide left-field option for Socceroos

fields.headline: Dutch experiences provide left-field option for Socceroos
fields.bodyText: Let’s get one thing straight: Jason Davidson hasn’t made a habit of scoring own goals. He hasn’t scored a single one at club level: not for Heracles, his current club in the Dutch top flight, nor during his time in the first division of Portugal, where he moved as a teenager. It’s worth clearing this up because for many Socceroos supporters Davidson is still that mysterious young player who came off the bench against Scotland last year and then headed one straight past Mark Schwarzer. A torturous inauguration to international football, and he never made it back on to the park under Holger Osieck. (Well, he did come on for the second half of the massacre in Paris, but given it was 4-0 within the first half hour, we can assume Osieck’s contract had already been torn up by the break.) Davidson has been a starting fixture at left-back in both games since, and shortly after play got under way against Costa Rica in Sydney last week it looked to many that he’d beaten his keeper again. Not so. “I didn’t really head it - the striker kicked it into my head, which was a bit unlucky. But thankfully it was stopped on the line.” It would have been particularly unfortunate, as it would have overshadowed a performance by the 22-year-old which won the admiration of new coach Ange Postecoglou and helped soothe the national anxiety about a perceived dearth of Australian left-backs. It was a performance that even included a role in the match-winning goal. “He played me through. They blocked my cross and it went out,” says Tommy Oar of the one-two leading up to the corner, which Oar took to set up the goal. “In the last 30 minutes we were dominating the game. He was getting forward and we combined together well.” The pair share a lot of history, having played together for years in the national youth teams, Davidson at left-back, Oar his partner on the left wing. “There’s some good chemistry there and I think it showed against Costa Rica,” says the defender. “We read each other well and played well with each other. And Tommy’s got a great engine, so it helps me, defending-wise, that he tracks his man back and he’s not lazy.” Team-mates one week, opponents the next. This weekend, the pair went head to head at club level in the Netherlands’ Eredivisie, with Davidson’s Heracles falling 2-1 at home to Oar’s FC Utrecht. Their last encounter, in May, also went the way of the visitors, and saw Davidson pick up the only red card of his professional career - one he can see a funny side of now. “I got milked by the striker. Tommy told me afterwards that the striker said he dived.” Both clubs are having inconsistent seasons: Heracles have beaten the likes of Feyenoord, but could only get a point against lowly NEC; at Utrecht, it’s been pretty much win-loss-win-loss since the opening round. On individual levels though, things are motoring ahead, with both now regulars in their starting line-ups. And as Postecoglou has made clear, getting regular game time is an invaluable commodity for a young player in a World Cup year – something that is currently eluding the other budding Socceroos plying their trade in the Eredivisie, Eli Babalj and Oar’s team-mate Adam Sarota, due to injury. “You can’t just turn the tap on and off,” says Davidson. “(Oar) has stepped up at the international level and (in the Costa Rica match) he did what he did because he’s doing it week in, week out at club level.” Oar agrees: “Playing well for your club maximises your chances with the national team, so my focus for now is on Utrecht and improving our position in the league.” Both players are big wraps for Postecoglou, and felt right at home with him at the helm. Davidson slotted easily into the new boss’s game plan because, as at club level, he was used as a hard-charging full-back in an 4-3-3 formation. “With Ange, he likes attacking full-backs, which is good because that suits my game to a tee. “And he’s given the youngsters a bit more of a go, and he’s given them a bit more confidence. I think that was the biggest difference for me. With Holger, I think everything was pretty much set in. So with me coming in later, he pretty much already had his players. Whereas with Ange, everybody is on a clean sheet and everyone was trying to impress him and get off to a good start.“ For Oar, the good performance in Sydney was a chance to repay the man who gave him his A-League debut and helped him get to Europe a few months later. “He was a great mentor for me,” he says of his coach at Brisbane Roar. “He was always very motivating and was always able to get the best out of his players. Why everybody respects him so much as a manager (is because) it’s always a level playing field for everybody. The same approach applies to everybody in the whole team. It’s not one rule for one person and different ones for another. “He’s a fantastic coach and he can take the Socceroos a long way.”
